resources.string:
Scrambled Net 

 Connect the terminals to the server by rotating the tiles 

 Touch a tile to rotate it; press and hold a tile to lock it when you think it's correct. 

 Use the menu to select different skill levels, pause the game, or start a new game.

 See the help in the menu for a full user's guide.

 Tap the screen to start.
At Master level, the board edges wrap around; cells on the right edge connect to those on the left edge, and vice versa. Similarly for the top and bottom edges

At Insane level, the board edges wrap around; cells on the right edge connect to those on the left edge, and vice versa. Similarly for the top and bottom edges. But in addition, in cells with 3 or 4 connections, the wiring is invisible. Good luck!

Scrambled Net is a simple puzzle game which requires you to sort out the connections in a computer network, so that all the terminals are connected to the server. The network is made up of tiles, and while all the tiles are in the right place, they have been rotated randomly into a useless mess.
\ 
\ You need to rotate individual tiles to re-connect the network. Tiles which are connected to the server are shown highlighted. When all terminals are connected, you've won.
\ 
\ It may seem simple at first, but try working your way up through the five difficulty levels. You may think the novice level is a blast, but I guarantee it gets more challenging when some of the tiles are invisible! If it gets too hard, try the hints below.
\

Use the menu to select different skill levels, pause the game, or start a new game 

 Tap a tile to rotate it once clockwise. Keep tapping until the tile is in the right orientation; if you need multiple turns to get it pointing the right way, that's still only counted as one click. 

 If you think that you have set a tile correctly, you can lock it in place. To lock a tile, press and hold the tile for a second; it will click and turn darker to indicate that it is locked. If you try to rotate a locked tile, it will display a flashing highlight. You can unlock it again by pressing and holding it. 

 Bear in mind that locking a tile is no indication that it is correct

Scrambled Net has five levels of difficulty. Higher skill levels have larger boards, and the most advanced levels have some special features:
\ 
\ • Novice gives you a small board to play with.
\ 
\ • Normal level has a somewhat larger board.
\ 
\ • Expert level uses a large board.
\ 
\ • Master level also uses a large board; but as an added challenge, the board "wraps around". This means that a connection can go off the right edge, for example, and connect to the corresponding tile on the left edge; the same applies to the top and bottom edges. Also, you'll find some 4-way connections thrown in to the mix.
\ 
\ • Insane level is the same as Master, but with the wrinkle that all 3-way and 4-way connections are invisible! You'll find that you need to figure out a whole new set of deductions to complete an insane puzzle. Be assured, though, that it can be done!
\ 
\ One last note: to take full advantage of your device's capabilities, the actual number of tiles in a board is different for different devices

The settings menu contains a number of options:
\ 
\ • New game starts a new game, abandoning the current game if any.
\ 
\ • Pause pauses the game, and covers the screen. Tap the screen to un-pause.
\ 
\ • High scores displays a table of your personal best scores — both the fewest clicks in which you've solved each difficulty level, and the fastest time. You can use the menu to reset your scores. Press "Back" to get back to the game.
\ 
\ • Skill level prompts you to select a skill level, then starts a new game at that skill level.
\ 
\ • Solve it! runs an autosolver to finish the current puzzle for you. If you get completely stuck, you can use this to see the solution — but you won't get personal best credit! While solving, this menu item changes to a "Stop" button, so you can stop the autosolver at any time.
\ 
\ • Sound lets you set your preferred sound effects level. However, the sound effects volume can always be adjusted in the game using the hardware volume keys. If no sound is coming out, try turning up the volume using the buttons.
\ 
\ • Animation lets you turn the "network data" animation on or off.
\ 
\ • Help displays this help.
\ 
\ • About displays version and license information

string.name: help_Hints_Content
string.item: Novice The edges are a good place to start - remember that a connection can never go off the edge of the board, so any tile which connects that way must be wrong. If a tile connects out to the right, then the next tile to the right must connect back to the left. In this way, once you have figured out one tile, you know something about the adjacent tiles.\n\ \n\ A tile which does not connect in a given direction also tells you something about the next tile in that direction

Normal You can sometimes finish a level without using all the tiles; but you can always finish a level by using all the tiles. So you may assume that all tiles must have a valid connection.\n\ \n\ Keep track of which tiles you know are correct by locking them - press and hold a tile to lock it (see \"Playing the Game\" above). But be sure that you really have them correct

Expert Expert mode is just the same as before, only larger - don\'t be discouraged!\n\ \n\ Terminals always have exactly one connection, and all terminals have to connect to the server. If two terminals connect together without a branch, there\'s no way to hook them to the server; so that must be wrong

Master In Master level, the edges no longer help you. Look for blocks of terminals together, and remember that two terminals can\'t be connected directly together. When you figure out one tile, look for all possible deductions you can make based on it

Insane In Insane level, you will need to make use of all the deductions you have figured out, plus at least one new one. Remember that only 3-way and 4-way tiles are invisible; so an invisible tile can often tell you something about its neighbours
